profileText: A Delegate from Idaho; born in Elyria, Lorain County, Ohio, May 6, 1836; attended the common schools and Oberlin (Ohio) College; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1859 and commenced practice in Elyria; Ohio, Weaverville, Calif., and Placerville, Idaho; lawyer, private practice; elected as a Democrat to the Thirty-ninth and succeeding Congress (March 4, 1865-March 3, 1869); censured by the U.S. House of Representatives on February 4, 1869, for use of unparliamentary language; was not a candidate for reelection to the Forty-first Congress in 1868; shot by Charles H. Douglas in Idaho City, Idaho, on June 17, 1870, and died from his wounds in that city the next day; interment in the Masonic Burial Ground.

researchRecord.name: 1869, 2 pages.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Edward Dexter Holbrook to Friend Moulton written on August 13, 1869. In the letter, Edward Holbrook describes mining affairs in Idaho. Also included is a newpaper clipping mounted on the second page giving an account of Edward Holbrook's death.

recordLocation.name: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

researchRecord.name: 1868, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Edward Dexter Holbrook to David S. Johnson describing the Idaho Territory.

researchRecord.name: 1866, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Edward Dexter Holbrook containing an autobiographical sketch.

researchRecord.name: In the John Rogers McBride Papers, n.d., 2 volumes.
researchRecord.description: Includes a biographical sketch of Edward Dexter Holbrook.
